metadata.swedish_title: Frontiers of Programming Language Technology, 7,5 högskolepoäng
metadata.specialization: A1F, Second cycle, has second-cycle course/s as entry requirements

sections.Confirmation:
This course syllabus was confirmed by Department of Computer Science and
Engineering on 2012-12-10 to be valid from 2013-09-02.
sections.Position in the educational system:
The course is a part of the Computer Science Master's Programme and a single-subject
course at the University of Gothenburg.
The course can be part of the following programme: 1) Computer Science, Master's
Programme (N2COS)
sections.Entry requirements:
The requirement for the course is to have successfully completed two years within the
subject Computer Science or equivalent. One of the courses: DIT331 Programming
Paradigms, DIT230 Programming Languages or DIT300 Compiler Construction or an
equivalent course is required.
English B level or English proficiency equivalent to IELTS 6.5 no part under 5.5 or
TOEFL 575 p, TWE score 4.5 is also required.
sections.Learning outcomes:
After completion of the course the student is expected to be able to:
Knowledge and understanding
• make informed choices about the design and use of advanced programming
language technology
Skill and abilities
• critically evaluate new programming languages and tools
• effectively assimilate and summarise advanced research material.
Judgement and approach
• identify the frontiers of research in the area of programming languages
sections.Course content:
This course aims to give insight into past, present and future programming language
technology, including introduction to the latest cutting edge research, including research
being conducted at Chalmers/University of Gothenburg (GU) in the area.The seminar
presents an overview of a wide selection of mainstream and experimental programming
languages and programming language technologies, and samples research articles from
the most influential programming language conferences, and current research at
GU/Chalmers.
sections.Assessment:
The course includes obligatory seminars and discussions.
The course is examined on the basis of individual oral presentations about programming
languages and about recent research papers in the area. The course is also examined by
a project work carried out in a group (normally in pairs) or individually and presented
at the end of the course.
A student who has failed the same examination twice has the right to request of the
department a change of examiner. The request is to be in writing and submitted as soon
as possible. The department is to grant such a request without delay.
In cases where a course has been discontinued or major changes have been made a
student should be guaranteed at least three examination occasions (including the
ordinary examination occasion) during a time of at least one year from the last time the
course was given.
sections.Grades:
The grading scale comprises: Fail (U), Pass (G), Pass with Distinction (VG).
To be awarded the grade Pass (G) for a full course the student must achieve a
satisfactory performance in the presentations and the project must be approved. In
addition the student must attend the obligatory meetings.
To be awarded the grade Pass with Distinction (VG) for a full course the student must
additionallty fulfil the following requirements.
For the presentations: demostrate technical insight ino material presented and
demonstrate very good communication and presentation skills. For the project:
demonstrate significant contribution to project results which show technical depth or
novelty with respect to overall aims of the course. In addition the student must attend
the obligatory meetings.
sections.Course evaluation:
The course is evaluated through meetings both during and after the course between
teachers and student representatives. Further, an anonymous questionnaire is used to
ensure written information. The outcome of the evaluations serves to improve the
course by indicating which parts could be added, improved, changed or removed.
sections.Additional information:
The course runs throughout the whole academic year, with regular seminars and
discussions, occasional exercises, and a finishing with presentations of project work.
Participants usually deliver several short presentations during the course, including
presentations about programming languages, research papers from recent top
conferences in programming language technology, and their own project work.
The course replaces the DIT760 course. The course cannot be included in a degree
which contains DIT760. Neither can the course be included in a degree which is based
on another degree in which the course DIT760 is included.
The syllabus corresponds to the syllabus of the Frontiers of Programming Language
Technology course at Chalmers.
